Award.AwardTitle: Assessing Weathering as a Function of Climate in Proximal Alluvial Sediments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Assessing Weathering as a Function of Climate in Proximal Alluvial Sediments

by
Gerilyn Sorghan, Megan Elwood-Madden, EAR-1225162, University of Oklahoma

ABSTRACT
Inferring a glacial influence from sedimentary facies is elusive, especially in the absence of ice-contact indicators (e.g., striated clasts). Illustrating this, inferences of glaciation on the basis of sedimentary facies have ignited controversies for sediments and sedimentary rocks from the murky depths of the Archean through the comparable light of the Pleistocene. Traditional chemical weathering indices are also ambiguous, particularly in discerning glacial/proglacial alluvial deposits from those formed in hot-arid systems. However, integrating chemical, mineralogical, and textural observations of alluvial sediments formed in temperature-precipitation extremes could provide valuable indicators of climate for sedimentary studies, particularly in distinguishing glacial from non-glacial systems. PIs propose to test the hypothesis that bulk chemistry, texture, and mineralogy, and solute fluxes of granitoid-sourced alluvial sediments show systematic and robust variations between glacial and non-glacial systems owing to differences in reactive surface area, temperature, and aqueous conditions. Accordingly, the objective of the proposed research is to quantify natural variation of chemical and physical weathering in granitoid-sourced proximal alluvial sediments in end-member glacial and non-glacial systems when other, "non-climatic" factors (e.g., provenance, drainage basin area and relief, sample grain size, sediment facies) are controlled. The ultimate goal is to establish a quantitative matrix of chemical and textural metrics to differentiate sediments formed in contrasting climates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report-- NSF 1225162

Intellectual Merit: This grant funded research aimed to test the hypothesis that chemical and textural attributes of river sediments formed in different (“end-member”) climates exhibit distinctive attributes imparted by weathering in these different climates. One ultimate goal was to establish quantitative measures of chemical and textural attributes of sediment that could be used as “markers” to interpret climate from sediments in Earth’s ancient record. (For example, to be able to infer, using our newly developed markers, the climatic conditions during formation of an ancient mudstone). To achieve this, we selected field sites for which we could hold constant, to the degree possible in natural systems, factors other than climate that influence weathering (e.g. type of bedrock, drainage basin area). We then targeted sites representing temperature and precipitation extremes, that included both glacial and non-glacial climates. We analyzed the bulk chemistry and mineralogy of the sediments, as well as the grain size, surface area, grain shape, and other textural features. In addition, we measured the reactivity of these sediments through both analyses of natural stream waters and laboratory experiments. All of these endeavors buttress our understanding of 1— how to better interpret Earth’s past climate using Earth’s ancient rock record, and 2— how rocks break down via weathering, which is absolutely critical to understanding how rock weathering influences carbon cycling and hence global climate.

Broader Impacts: Improved understanding of both Earth’s past climate and rock weathering processes are relevant to issues of societal concern, such as how to effectively sequester carbon in an increasingly carbon-constrained world, and how to improve climate models by better interpretation of climate markers in Earth’s rock record. Additionally, this grant provided funds that helped train one post-doctoral researcher, two PhD students, one M.S. student, and four undergraduate students from the University of Oklahoma, and two undergraduate students from the University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez. In addition to completing dissertations, and graduate and undergraduate theses, these students participated in four published papers in the peer-reviewed literature to date (and more in preparation), and ten presentations made at professional science meetings.
